bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Albert E. Truby, February 18, 1948

div1.p: Siler agrees with Truby that many changes occurred to the interior of the building where Reed died. Siler will go to Fort McNair in an attempt to secure earlier plans of the hospital.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Albert E. Truby, February 18, 1948
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
1835 EYE STREET. NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
February 18, 1948
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 15th. The
package containing the plans of the hospital reached me some days after
receipt of your first letter and I have gone over them and quite agree with
you that it will be necessary to secure still earlier plans if we are to
definitely locate the room in which Walter Reed died.

I have just come from a visit with General Lawrence Reed and, as it
happened, Blossom was visiting them. They all agreed with you and with
Gen. Kean and myself that in view of the many changes that have occurred in
the inside plans of the building, it will be wise to limit the placing of
the plaques to one on the outside of the building itself. However, in a short
time I shall go down to Fort Leslie J. McNair and try to secure earlier plans
of the hospital and it may be possible for us to locate the room more exactly.

As I wrote you several days ago, I got in touch with Gen. McCoy and he
will be glad to see Dr. Hench. I have not yet heard from the latter but I
read in the newspaper that he is to address a medical society meeting here
tonight and I hope to get in touch with him sometime today and arrange to see
him tomorrow morning.

In talking with General Reed and Blossom they both told me that there
evidently must be some mixup in the matter of Walter Reed being pulled off
the work in Cuba and sent to the Philippines. Blossom remembers very dis-
tinctly that her father had been here in Washington for a somewhat long
period of time and it became necessary to order him elsewhere in order to
comply with the regulations at that time. General Sternberg in the spring
of 1900 ordered him to the Philippines but before he could comply with that
order he was sent down to Cuba to investigate a outbreak of yellow fever in
one of the companies of one of the regiments on duty there. Following that
temporary duty, the order to the Philippines was held up and he was ordered
to Cuba as a member of the Board. Blossom says that so far as she knows,
no effort was made to carry out the order to the Philippines during the course
of his work in Cuba. It is quite possible that we can get some further in-
formation concerning this matter from General McCoy.

Within a few days I will be glad to take up with the Office of the Sur-
geon General the matter of the location of your books. I do hope that it will
be possible for you to come to Washington for the Walter Reed Celebration and
it is possible that Sawyer will have sufficient funds to pay your expenses.
This he will know within a short time and he will advise you accordingly.
I shall write you further after I have seen Dr. Hench.
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, J. F. Siler, Col., U.S.A. Ret. Gen. Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel St
San Francisco 18, Cal
